title: Marshmallow Madness
question_text:
Breakfast cereal with marshmallows is very popular among children (and adults too!). Brand 'A' marshmallow cereal has an average of $31.5\text{ marshmallows per cup}$ with a standard deviation of $6.0\text{ marshmallows}$. Brand 'B' marshmallow cereal has an average of $35.6\text{ marshmallows per cup}$ with a standard deviation of $7.6\text{ marshmallows}$.
What is the probability that randomly chosen samples of $35\text{ cups}$ of each cereal would show a larger average number of marshmallows from Brand A?

choices.text: The conditions for using the normal model might not be met in this situation. More information is needed.
